Specifically, Figure 1A–C shows a hexagonal particle (#1
particle) with a diameter of around 80 nm.

Another representative particle (#2 particle) shown in aggregates
of multiple amorphous spherical particles contained Si, O, and N (Figure 1D–G).

Si-containing
particles have also been widely found in both occupational exposure
and natural atmosphere, and often applied as model AFPs for cytotoxicity
studies.39,42 The Si particles found here harbored complex
compositions, suggesting that these particles might derive from the
exogenous environment.40
Figure 1.

Figure 2 shows representative
particles observed in the intraocular fluid specimens.

One aggregate
of particles (#3 particle) appeared with an amorphous morphology and
a diameter of approximately 20 nm (Figure 2A).

The detailed recognition of the fingerprint
information, including elementary compositions, structure, and crystal
lattice indexing unveiled that the particles consisted of gold oxide
(Au2O3, PDF-#: 43–1039) and petrovskaite
(AgAuS, PDF-#: 38–0396) (Figure 2B–F).

Another aggregate of particles (#4 particle)
was identified as argentite (Au2S, PDF-#: 04–0774)
with a diameter of approximately 30 nm, through fingerprint information,
including elementary compositions, structure, and crystal lattice
(Figure 2G–K).

Specifically, Figure 1A–C shows a hexagonal particle (#1
particle) with a diameter of around 80 nm.

Another representative particle (#2 particle) shown in aggregates
of multiple amorphous spherical particles contained Si, O, and N (Figure 1D–G).

Figure 2 shows representative
particles observed in the intraocular fluid specimens.

One aggregate
of particles (#3 particle) appeared with an amorphous morphology and
a diameter of approximately 20 nm (Figure 2A).

The detailed recognition of the fingerprint
information, including elementary compositions, structure, and crystal
lattice indexing unveiled that the particles consisted of gold oxide
(Au2O3, PDF-#: 43–1039) and petrovskaite
(AgAuS, PDF-#: 38–0396) (Figure 2B–F).

Another aggregate of particles (#4 particle)
was identified as argentite (Au2S, PDF-#: 04–0774)
with a diameter of approximately 30 nm, through fingerprint information,
including elementary compositions, structure, and crystal lattice
(Figure 2G–K).

Remarkably,
we also found argentite particles (#4 particle) in the blood specimen
from the same patient, whose intraocular fluid was found to contain
argentite particles (Figure 2G–K).

As shown in Figure 3, argentite particles with a constant morphology
and size of around 30 nm were found in the serum sample.

Remarkably,
we also found argentite particles (#4 particle) in the blood specimen
from the same patient, whose intraocular fluid was found to contain
argentite particles (Figure 2G–K).

As shown in Figure 3, argentite particles with a constant morphology
and size of around 30 nm were found in the serum sample.

To uncover the exposure concentrations of particles in human eyes
and the internal pathway of AFP translocation through BOB, we collected
samples from 4 different types of eye diseases and applied NTA for
measuring the number concentrations of particles in intraocular fluids
(Figure 4A).31 Note that it has been proposed in many studies
that the incidence of the 4 eye diseases in the female population
is higher than that in the male population.54−57 As established, the exposure
dose of AFPs decides toxicity so that the dose needs to be investigated
to evaluate the concrete (cyto)toxicity to the eyes.

As shown in Figure 4B, the NTA data showed that particles were widely present
in all
of the intraocular fluid samples.

As shown in Figure 4B, the particle concentrations in eyes varied
in various diseases.

To be specific, it appeared that the particle
concentration in intraocular fluids from PDR was approximately 6.03
times greater than that from myopia (Figure 4C, P < 0.01).

Furthermore,
the particle concentration in intraocular fluids from some vitreoretinal
interface disorders, namely, MH (approximately 1.20 times, P < 0.05) and ERM (approximately 1.47 times, P < 0.05), was much higher than that from myopia (Figure 4D,E).

The concentration of particles in serums ranged from
1.05 × 107 to 1.72 × 108 particles/mL
(Figure 4F).

Strikingly,
the particle concentrations in intraocular fluids were rather higher
(approximately 9.49 times) than that in serum (Figure 4F, P < 0.001).

Moreover, the size of particles in serum was 1.52 times larger
than that in the intraocular fluids (Figure 4G, P < 0.001) as characterized
by NTA analysis (Figure 4F).

The db/db mice were first examined
by fundus angiography (Figure 5A).

The results showed that these db/db mice bore more microangiomas
(red arrows), with dilated vessels in the retina (yellow arrows) relative
to the healthy control group (Figure 5B,C).

Remarkably, we found particles both
in the anterior chamber (red circles, Figure 5D–G) and in the vitreous body (red
circles, Figure 5H–K)
in vivo.

Moreover, there were particles found in both the anterior
chamber and the vitreous body of healthy mice and diabetes mice (Figure 5G,K), indicating
the translocation pathway of particles from the lung to the eyes,
and accumulation of particles in the eyes.

In addition, the quantification of Au particles accumulated
in the eyes was consistent with the OCT results; in other words, Au
particle accumulations in diabetes (approximately 10.08 times, P < 0.01) and healthy eyes (approximately 2.36 times, P < 0.05) were greater than that in the untreated control
group (Figure 5G).

Moreover, the Au particle accumulation in diabetes eyes was 4.28 times
greater than that in healthy eyes (P < 0.05),
stressing that the exogenous particles were more readily enriched
in the eyes with retinal lesions (Figure 5H).

In specific, compared with control eyes
where there was no evidence of foreign particles (Figure 5M), aggregates of fluorescence-labeled
particles were found in the vitreous body (near the retina) of the
exposed mice (red arrows, Figure 5N).

Moreover, a cardinal
transport pathway of particles from the lung to the eye via the bloodstream
and BOB is also recognized (Figure 6).
